;
;;Rishi Sunak 离开 10 号
;

;高级保守党敦促 Rishi Sunak 使用他的下一份宣言解决他们的政党在年轻选民中令人震惊的不受欢迎的问题，人们越来越担心，如果不采取紧急行动赢得 40 岁以下的选民，保守党可能会“沉没”。

;

;温和派保守党越来越担心该党;未能优先考虑政策内阁部长汤姆·图根哈特（Tom Tugendhat）是该党自由派的傀儡之一，他已成为公开敦促重新考虑的最高级人物之一。在温和的保守党改革集团的一次集会上，安全部长警告说，该党不能再“坐视”并假设选民随着年龄的增长会简单地转向该党 - 他警告说这是一个假设可能不再是这样。

;

;“这个国家没有一个保守党不相信人们拥有一个家、一个家庭——无论这个家庭是什么样子——的机会是至关重要的，我们他上周在集会上表示：“我们需要成为有抱负的政党，通过保守党政策帮助人们实现这一理想。”

;

;他补充道：“在某些领域我们可以做得更多，特别是当给年轻人和下一代。

;
;

;;相关：;;为什么千禧一代对保守党如此反感？;

;
;

;“我们需要确保年轻人人们有机会帮助他们取得成功，我们不能让他们落后。让我们看看我们为 30 岁以下的人提供了什么，特别是当涉及到任何未来的宣言时。

;

;“曾经有一段时间，人们说选民在 40 岁时会变得保守。我不确定这必然是事实，但我们不能坐等这种情况发生。”

;

;图根哈特表示，向年轻选民提出的任何提议都必须包括遵守该党到 2050 年实现净零排放的承诺，尽管人们对保守党右翼的政策越来越不安。 “我们知道年轻人也希望从我们这里看到什么样的政策 - 我们知道他们关心环境，作为保守党，这呼应了我们自己对环境保护的承诺，”他说。

;

;“这是其中之一我们需要保留绿色政策的原因，我们可以看到这些政策创造了数以千计的就业机会并促进了我们的绿色基础设施。”

;

;他的评论是《观察家报》最新的 Opinium 民意调查; 透露，随着关键的党派会议季节即将到来，工党仍领先保守党 15 个百分点。结果显示，工党在 18 岁至 34 岁选民中领先 46 个百分点。去年的 Opinium 民意调查显示，工党在年龄组中领先 40 个百分点或以上。

;

;图根哈特的观点反映了议员们更广泛的担忧。前部长、温布尔登议员斯蒂芬·哈蒙德表示：“很难不同意汤姆的评论。如果我们没有能够引起下一代选民共鸣的政策，我们就会陷入困境。我们需要建设更多，推动环保型增长，并为未来的科技世界创造就业技能。”

;

;自由党保守党一直在努力推动该党对专业人士表现出更多热情。 -绿色政策，;苏纳克最近批评了应对气候危机的“毛衫”方法。

;

;财政大臣杰里米·亨特也发誓不会收养乔拜登的“补贴碗”方法，指的是总统的;减少通货膨胀法案;旨在帮助美国实现净零碳经济。

;

;还有;通货膨胀减少法案;，旨在帮助美国实现净零碳经济。 theguardian.com/money/2023/aug/10/no-fault-eviction-proceedings-highest-six-years-england" title="">;对租户改革的延迟感到沮丧;英格兰得到更多保护。

;

;与此同时，苏纳克也面临着来自右翼政党的压力，要求他不要放弃养老金三重锁定，据了解，财政部正在探索临时调整政策的方法，以挽救养老金。 10 亿英镑。

;

;保守党改革集团全国主席西沃恩·阿伦斯 (Siobhan Aarons) 表示：“需要采取更多措施来解决代际不公平问题。这并不意味着我们必须废除三重锁定来惩罚一组选民来支持另一组选民，但我们必须表明我们了解 20 多岁、30 多岁和 40 多岁的人面临的挑战。

;

;“这是现在，人们在 50 岁时更有可能投票给保守党，这绝非巧合。我们为年轻一代提供了什么？不能只是大同小异。

;

;“明年任何明智的宣言都需要将政策重点放在英国（不仅仅是伦敦）的住房、租金改革、儿童保育成本、基础设施投资和更环保的政策上。 13 年后，本届政府需要更加大胆地推动就业和经济增长，这将使几代选民受益。”

;

;保守党温和派全年都在讨论向年轻选民提供的优惠。比姆·阿弗拉米（Bim Afolami），前保守党副主席，直到鲍里斯·约翰逊担任首相期间辞职，;警告该问题可能对该党“存在”;。

;
;

;;相关：;;Jann Wenner 于 2022 年在纽约。Wenner，滚石杂志的创始人，也是 The Rock 的联合创始人&滚石名人堂已被除名。;

;滚石杂志联合创始人、摇滚名人堂联合创始人 Jann Wenner 已被除名在发表了被视为诽谤黑人和女性音乐家的言论后，詹恩·温纳 (Jann Wenner) 已被从摇滚名人堂基金会董事会中除名，”周六，即温纳在《纽约时报》采访中发表评论的第二天，霍尔说。

;

;77 岁的温纳代表没有立即回应置评。

;
;

; ;相关：;;滚石乐队的 Jann Wenner ：“有些评论实在令人难以忍受”;

;
;

;这场争议源于温纳在宣传他的新书《大师》时接受的采访，其中采访了音乐家鲍勃·迪伦、杰里·加西亚、米克·贾格尔、约翰·列侬、布鲁斯·斯普林斯汀、皮特·汤森德和 U2 的波诺——都是白人和男性。

;

;当被问及为什么他不采访女性或黑人音乐家时，温纳回答道：“这并不是说他们是虽然不善言辞，但还是去和 Grace Slick 或 Janis Joplin 进行深入的交谈吧。请做我的客人。你知道，乔尼·米切尔并不是一位摇滚哲学家。在我看来，她没有达到那个标准。”他告诉《泰晤士报》。

;

;“黑人艺术家——你知道，史蒂夫·旺德，天才，对吧？我想当你使用像“大师”这样广泛的词时，错误就在于使用这个词。也许是马文·盖伊，或者柯蒂斯·梅菲尔德？我的意思是，他们只是没有达到那个水平。”Wenner 说。

;

;Wenner 于 1967 年创立了《滚石》，并担任其编辑或编辑总监直至 2019 年。他是摇滚厅的联合创始人of Fame 于 1987 年推出。

;

;在采访中，温纳似乎承认他将面临强烈反对。 “出于公共关系的考虑，也许我应该去找一位黑人和一位女性艺术家，将他们纳入其中，而这些艺术家并没有达到同样的历史标准，只是为了避免这种批评。”

;

;去年，《滚石》杂志公布了有史以来最伟大的 500 张专辑，其中盖伊的《What's Going On》排名第一，米切尔的《Blue》排名第三，Wonder 的《Songs in the Key of Life》排名第四，Prince 的《Purple Rain》和排名第 8 的《革命》和排名第 10 的劳伦·希尔女士的《劳伦·希尔的错误教育》。

; Sun, 17 Sep 2023 10:22:02 +0800 California sues oil companies claiming they downplayed the risk of fossil fuelshttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/sep/17/california-sues-oil-companies-claiming-they-downplayed-the-risk-of-fossil-fuels
;;2023-09-17T00:20:10Z;
;
;;加利福尼亚州州长加文·纽瑟姆向记者发表讲话。该州已对一些全球最大的石油和天然气公司提起诉讼。
;

;加州已对一些全球最大的石油和天然气公司提起诉讼，声称他们欺骗公众并淡化所带来的风险

;

;向旧金山州高等法院提起的民事诉讼还寻求设立一个由这些公司资助的基金，以支付毁灭性风暴和火灾后的恢复工作费用。民主党州长加文·纽瑟姆 (Gavin Newsom) 在一份声明中表示，诉讼中点名的公司——埃克森美孚、壳牌、雪佛龙、康菲石油公司和英国石油公司——应该承担责任。

;

;“50多年来，石油巨头一直在撒谎。对我们来说——掩盖了这样一个事实，即他们很早就知道他们生产的化石燃料对我们的星球有多么危险，”纽瑟姆说。 “加州纳税人不应该为数十亿美元的损失买单——野火摧毁了整个社区，有毒烟雾堵塞了我们的空气，致命的热浪，破纪录的干旱烧焦了我们的水井。”

;

;长达 135 页的投诉称，这些公司至少从 20 世纪 60 年代就知道燃烧化石燃料会使地球变暖并改变气候，但他们在公开声明和营销中淡化了迫在眉睫的威胁。

;

;诉讼称，早在 20 世纪 50 年代，这些公司的科学家就知道气候影响将是灾难性的，而且社区和政府能够做出反应的时间窗口很短。

;

;相反，诉讼称，这些公司至少早在 20 世纪 70 年代就开始了一场虚假信息宣传活动，旨在抹黑关于气候变化日益增长的科学共识，并质疑与气候变化相关的风险。

;

;美国石油协会，一个也被命名为行业组织在诉讼中，他表示气候政策应该在国会而不是法庭上进行辩论。

;

;“这场针对美国基础工业及其工人发起毫无根据的政治化诉讼的持续、协调一致的运动只不过是一种干扰该研究所高级副总裁瑞安·迈耶斯 (Ryan Meyers) 在一份声明中表示：“这种做法剥夺了重要的全国性对话的机会，也是对加州纳税人资源的巨大浪费。”壳牌公司的一份声明也呼应了这一点，该公司表示，法庭不是适当的法庭。解决全球变暖问题的场所。

;

;“应对气候变化需要采取全社会协作的方法，”该能源公司表示。 “我们同意现在需要对气候变化采取行动，我们完全支持社会向低碳未来过渡的需要。”

;

;加利福尼亚州的法律行动加入了各州和市政府最近提起的类似诉讼。

;

;“加州的诉讼进一步增强了追究大型石油公司数十年欺骗行为责任的势头，并确保遭受化石燃料极端天气和缓发灾害（例如，海平面上升”，忧思科学家联盟的凯西·穆尔维 (Kathy Mulvey) 说道。

;

;在谈到法律诉讼时，加利福尼亚州总检察长罗布·邦塔 (Rob Bonta) 在一份声明中表示，这些公司“向我们灌输谎言和不实事实，以进一步推动他们的行为”。创纪录的利润是以牺牲我们的环境为代价的。受够了。”

;

;诉讼中的指控包括指责这些公司制造或加剧了加州的气候变化、虚假广告、破坏自然资源以及在气候变化问题上欺骗公众的非法商业行为。<气候完整性中心主席理查德·威尔斯在一份声明中表示，“加州决定将大型石油公司告上法庭，这是一场迅速扩大的法律斗争的一个分水岭，这场斗争旨在追究主要污染者数十年来的责任。气候谎言……加州人一直生活在化石燃料工业造成的气候紧急状态中，现在该州正在采取果断行动，让这些污染者付出代价。”

;Liz Truss 将声称 Rishi Sunak 政府的支出比她多 350 亿英镑周一的一次演讲中，这位短命的首相将利用在政府研究所的一次演讲来捍卫和解释她的执政时间，距她患病已近一年了。命中注定的迷你预算帮助结束了她的首相任期。

;

;据《电讯报》报道，特拉斯将指出，根据她的计划，2023-24 年将节省 184 亿英镑，2024 年还可节省 171 亿英镑-25.

;

;“我想要做的是通过抑制支出并不允许在即将到来的支出审查期间发生任何新的支出来改变支出轨迹，”该报报道她会说。

;

;“考虑到通货膨胀水平，不重新启动支出审查代表着对支出采取强硬态度。”

;

;她会说，这一决定将在 2023 年节省 136 亿英镑——与苏纳克的公共支出计划相比，2024-25 年将节省 24 亿英镑，2024-25 年将节省 123 亿英镑。

;

;根据工资而非通货膨胀增加福利的计划也将在两年内节省 96 亿英镑。

;

;“与我们现在的支出相比，我们将在 2023-24 年节省 184 亿英镑，在 2024-25 年节省 171 亿英镑，”她会说。

;

;她会补充道： “即使是这些微薄的储蓄也没有得到议会党的支持。

;

;“对于我们这些希望看到规模较小的政府的人来说，这是一个非常严重的问题，而目前对支出进行重大改变根本无法实现。拥有足够的政治支持。”

;

;这是这位前保守党领袖最新的公开干预，他在去年夏天的保守党党魁竞选中击败了苏纳克，并于 10 月辞职。

; Sun, 17 Sep 2023 06:52:01 +0800 Letter suggests Pope Pius XII knew of mass gassings of Jews and Poles in 1942https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/16/letter-suggests-pope-pius-xii-knew-of-mass-gassings-of-jews-and-poles-in-1942
;;2023-09-16T22:34:54Z;
;
;;教皇庇护十二世领导服务
;

;新发现的信件表明第二次世界大战时期教皇庇护十二世从一位值得信赖的德国耶稣会士那里得到了详细信息，称在德占波兰每天有多达 6,000 名犹太人和波兰人被毒气处死。该文件削弱了梵蒂冈的论点，即它无法核实纳粹暴行的外交报告以谴责它们。

;

;本周末在意大利日报《晚邮报》上发表的梵蒂冈档案馆的文件可能会进一步加剧关于庇护的遗产和他现在陷入困境的列真福活动的争论。

;

;历史学家长期以来对庇护的记录存在分歧，支持者坚持认为他使用安静的外交来拯救犹太人的生命，而批评者则说他在大屠杀肆虐时保持沉默

;

;《Corriere》转载了 1942 年 12 月 14 日德国耶稣会神父写给庇护的秘书的一封信，这封信包含在一本即将出版的书中，该书由乔瓦尼·科科 (Giovanni Coco) 撰写，介绍庇护的教宗新打开的档案，乔瓦尼·科科 (Giovanni Coco) 是一名研究员和档案管理员。梵蒂冈的使徒档案。

;

;可可告诉《晚邮报》，这封信意义重大，因为它代表了有关纳粹灭绝犹太人（包括用烤箱）的详细信件，这些信件来自德国一位消息灵通的教会消息人士，该消息人士是天主教反政府组织的一部分。 - 希特勒抵抗组织能够向梵蒂冈获取其他秘密信息。

;

;牧师 Lothar Koenig 写给庇护的秘书、德国耶稣会士罗伯特·雷伯牧师 (Rev Robert Leiber) 的信，日期为 14 1942 年 12 月。这封信用德文写成，称莱伯为“亲爱的朋友”，并接着报告说，纳粹每天在拉瓦鲁斯卡（战前波兰的一个城镇，今天位于乌克兰境内）杀害多达 6,000 名犹太人和波兰人。并将他们运送到贝尔热克死亡营。

;

;根据 2004 年开放的贝尔热克纪念馆的数据，共有 50 万犹太人在该集中营丧生。纪念馆的网站报道称，1942 年初，多达 3,500 名来自拉瓦鲁斯卡的犹太人已被送往贝尔热克，12 月 7 日至 11 日，该市的犹太隔都被清理。该网站称：“大约 3,000-5,000 人当场被枪杀，2,000-5,000 人被带到贝乌热茨。”

;

;科尼格信函的日期很重要，因为它暗示了来自一位值得信赖的耶稣会士的信件。从 1942 年 8 月起，隔都被清空后，庇护斯收到多份外交照会和多位外国政府特使的来访，报告称迄今为止有多达 100 万犹太人在波兰被杀害。 .

;

;虽然不能确定皮乌斯是否看过这封信，但雷伯是他的高级助手，并且在 1920 年代担任梵蒂冈驻德国大使时曾为教皇服务过，这表明双方存在密切的工作关系，尤其是在

;

;根据普利策奖得主人类学家戴维·科泽 (David Kertzer) 所著的《战争中的教皇》，国家官员的高级秘书多梅尼科·塔尔迪尼 (Domenico Tardini) 主教在 12 月中旬告诉英国驻梵蒂冈特使：教皇无法公开谈论纳粹暴行，因为梵蒂冈无法核实这些信息。

;

;《晚邮报》援引可可的话说：“这份文件的新颖性和重要性来自于这一事实：关于大屠杀，现在可以肯定的是，庇护十二世从德国天主教会收到了有关针对犹太人犯下的罪行的准确而详细的消息。”

; Sun, 17 Sep 2023 04:22:02 +0800 Garrick could admit women after barrister U-turns on club ruleshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/16/garrick-could-admit-women-after-barrister-u-turns-on-club-rules
;;2023-09-16T17:24:01Z;
;
;;The Garrick Club, London.
;

;One of London's last remaining gentlemen's clubs, the Garrick, may be edging towards admitting women after a barrister performed a U-turn on a previous legal judgment ruling that they were ineligible for membership.

;

;Michael Beloff KC first concluded that women could not be proposed under the club's rules after Joanna Lumley was denied membership in 2011. He ruled then that although the rules do not explicitly preclude women from joining, they state that “no candidate shall be eligible unless he be proposed by one member and seconded by another”.

;

;The use of the masculine article led Beloff to conclude that the rule could be interpreted as referring to men only, while he also said the club's objectives also refer to “gentlemanly accomplishment and scholarship”.

;

;But the rule could now be scrapped in the club, which was founded in 1831 and counts Benedict Cumberbatch and Sir Kingsley Amis among its members, after the KC wrote a new legal opinion, concluding the opposite.

;

;Beloff prepared a new legal opinion in November last year, the Times reports, stating that there was “now a cogent argument” that the Law of Property Act 1925 means “he” and “she” can be used interchangeably in contracts.

;

;“If so, there is no legal obstacle to the proposal of a woman for membership of the club by one member, seconded by another; nor, if she obtains the support required under the rules, any legal obstacle to her admission as a member of the club,” the newspaper quotes Beloff as writing. He reportedly warned that the club was “likely to provoke an expensive lawsuit” if it continued to exclude women from membership.

;

;Although the opinion was delivered in November, many members only became aware of it recently, as the committee had not shared the news of Beloff's revised judgment, the Times reports. Club members will share their views on women joining in a survey next month.

;

;Emily Bendell, the chief executive and founder of a successful underwear brand, ;launched legal action against the club; in 2020, arguing that its men-only membership rules are a breach of equality legislation, while ;Cherie Booth KC joined a campaign; to force the club to admit women the following year.

;

;Members including Stephen Fry, Damian Lewis and Hugh Bonneville have said they were in favour of extending membership to women, as has Michael Gove, the former justice secretary Ken Clarke, and broadcasters Sir Trevor McDonald, Melvyn Bragg and Jeremy Paxman. Three former Conservative MPs and 11 KCs were among those who said they would vote to continue to exclude female members.

;

;The club, which was founded in 1831, last voted on whether to include women in 2015, when a majority of 50.5% voted in favour of introducing female membership. However, the introduction of a new rule at the Garrick requires a two-thirds majority.

;

;The Garrick has been contacted for comment.

;

;The shadow foreign secretary, David Lammy, has proposed regular meetings between UK and European Union ministers, as part of a major reset of British foreign policy under a Labour government.

;

;Lammy, who was attending a gathering of centre-left leaders in Montreal, Canada, with the Labour leader Keir Starmer, told the ;Observer; it was high time the UK took up its place again, after Brexit, as a lead player in world affairs. “A UK that is isolated and missing is felt across the world. It is definitely the case that the international community want Britain back,” he said.

;

;“There have always been two visions of Britain. Great Britain, outward looking, internationalist, connected. And Little England, which is unfortunately what is being pursued by Rishi Sunak.”

;

;Last night, as Starmer used a speech at the meeting hosted by the Canadian prime minister Justin Trudeau to say Labour would rebuild “the smouldering cinders of the bridges the Tories have burnt” in relations with other countries, Lammy said closer links with the EU were the number one goal.

;

;“We do think that UK relations with the European Union is our top priority. We can't imagine describing, as Liz Truss did, ;Emmanuel Macron as an enemy;,” he said. “We think it is bizarre that the UK does not currently under this government have structured dialogue with the European Union in a constructive way. We want to approach the review of our trade arrangements in a very constructive manner, and we want to build on the partnership that we have seen on Ukraine. That is why we are proposing a new [UK/EU] security pact.”

;

;Lammy stressed that a Labour government would not attempt to take Britain back into the EU single market or customs union but added that “we do think there is a lot we can do in ;rebuilding our relationships; if we are in power. We don't currently meet with the European Union to discuss mutual issues of concern, whether on a biannual basis or on a quarterly basis. At the moment there is nothing. It is all ad hoc. We have got to get back to structured dialogue. What it means [without it] is that we are not in the room.”

;

;The EU currently has regular bilateral summits with other countries, including the US, China, Canada, Australia and Japan. It is understood that initial talks about creating regular UK/EU meetings have taken place, with Brussels reacting positively.

; ;

;The comments by both Starmer and Lammy reflect a greater confidence at the top of the party to talk about ;relations between the UK and the EU; than has been the case under Starmer's leadership to date. Until now, there has been a fear that pro-Brexit Labour voters and the right-wing media would accuse Starmer of wanting to overturn the result of the 2016 referendum.

;

;The shift of gear by Starmer and raising of his profile on the international stage has echoes of the efforts made by New Labour before it came to power in 1997 to court both Washington and the EU, as it sought to act as bridge between them. Tony Blair famously courted the Democrats, and in April 1996, more than a year before his first general election victory, was invited by President Bill Clinton to take part in a joint press conference at the White House.

;

;Lammy and the shadow chancellor, Rachel Reeves, will join Starmer on Tuesday on a visit to Paris where the Labour leader will hold talks with Macron, including about his plans to tackle the problem of small boats crossing the channel.

;

;Starmer indicated last week during a ;visit to Europol; in The Hague that he could strike a deal with Brussels that would involve taking a quota of asylum seekers who arrive in the EU in exchange for the ability to return people who cross the Channel.

;

;Then Lammy will travel to Washington with the shadow defence secretary, John Healey, later next week for meetings with US Democrat and Republican politicians and officials. Lammy said they would be stressing the UK's solidarity with Ukraine amid signs of waning public support in the US for the war against Russia.

;

;Lammy said it was “unbelievable” that Sunak had decided to become the first British prime minister in a decade not to attend the UN general assembly in New York this week. The shadow international development secretary, Lisa Nandy, will be representing the Labour party.

;

;In his speech in Montreal last night, Starmer challenged Sunak to face down those Conservative MPs who ;want Britain to pull out; of the European convention on human rights, saying Sunak's “equivocation” was damaging Britain's global influence and preventing the country from leading on the world stage.

;

;“Their drum beat of threats to pull out of the ECHR is nothing more than a desperate attempt by a failing government to whip up division in order to cling to power, with the consequences for Britain's security and prosperity an afterthought,” he said.

;

;Lammy said Sunak had been isolated at the G20 last weekend when the United States, the EU and India joined in signing an agreement on an ;India-Middle East economic corridor; at the G20, with the UK prime minister not present.

;During Saturday's senate voting session, which required 21 votes to convict Paxton on any one article, the majority of senators voted along party lines to acquit. Republicans currently dominate the chamber with a 19-12 majority.

;

;Most of the impeachment articles saw votes of 14 yays and 16 nays. Article 3, which concerned the abuse of the open records process, saw the widest disparity in votes, with two yays and 28 nays.

;

;Paxton himself was not present in the chamber during the votes.

;

;Paxton's trial saw testimonies from former employees of the attorney general's office who blew the whistle on their boss's questionable conduct to the FBI and Nate Paul, a wealthy Republican campaign donor and Austin real estate developer with whom Paxton exchanged favors, such as asking Paul to employ his former girlfriend. ;
;

;After pleading not guilty, Paxton was absent for nearly the entire trial – a fact that frustrated his prosecutors. ; ;

;Paxton's tenure as attorney general has been plagued with ;controversies; from the beginning. In 2014, before he was elected, he was fined by the Texas state securities board for violating financial laws. And the scandals snowballed from there.

;

;Paxton's former employers reported him to federal authorities for abusing his power by accepting bribes in the form of donations from Paul. ;

;At one point during Saturday's voting session, Blake Brickman – the former deputy attorney general for policy strategy and one of the whistleblowers who reported Paxton to federal authorities – ;walked out; of the chamber, KXAN's Monica Madden reported.

;

;Paxton was formally ;impeached; in May and immediately suspended from his duties as attorney general.

;

;In language that seemed to mirror that of Republican ally and former president Trump, Paxton's defense attorneys ;described; the impeachment as a political witch-hunt. But unlike with Trump, it was largely other Republicans who turned on Paxton.

;A far-right figure in Texas, Paxton is the architect of some of the most severe voting restrictions imposed on the state and favors statewide bans on reproductive choice and gender-affirming care.
